explanation:
For each listed symbol, explain why it is required to judge MISRA rule compliance for any for-loops that affect or are affected by answer_to_connection:

- struct connection_info_struct
  Need the full definition (fields: answerstring, postprocessor, connectiontype, etc.) to see which objects are stored in *req_cls and whether any of those fields might be loop counters or be modified in potential for-loop bodies (rule forbids loop counters being modified in the body and forbids use of objects modified in the body in the loop test/update).

- iterate_post
  This callback is passed to MHD_create_post_processor and may be invoked by MHD_post_process. The rule states the behaviour of a for-loop body includes called functions, so any for-loops inside iterate_post (or side effects it performs on objects used as loop counters) must be inspected.

- POSTBUFFERSIZE
  The buffer size passed into the post-processor may influence loop bounds inside post-processing routines or callbacks; include to understand loop-control expressions that might depend on it.

- MHD_create_post_processor
  Prototype/behaviour is required to know what postprocessor object is created, how callbacks are registered, and whether its creation or returned object influences loop control or shared state used in loops.

- MHD_PostProcessor (type)
  The concrete type of con_info->postprocessor and its semantics: needed to determine what objects are modified by post-processing calls and whether those objects could appear in for-loop conditions/updates.

- MHD_post_process
  This is called from answer_to_connection; its implementation must be inspected for any for-loops and for side effects on objects that might serve as loop counters in any for-loop that calls it.

- post_process_urlencoded, post_process_multipart
  These are the internal routines MHD_post_process may call. They are likely places for parsing loops; their loops and side-effects must be inspected because their behaviour is part of the for-loop body (per MISRA wording).

- send_page
  Called from answer_to_connection. Any for-loops in send_page (or its callees) are part of the called behaviour; include to check for improperly formed for statements and for uses/modifications of objects visible to answer_to_connection.

- askpage, errorpage
  The page data objects passed to send_page — include to determine whether send_page loops depend on or modify these objects (and whether such objects are used as loop counters or condition flags elsewhere).

- MHD_Result (enum) and MHD_YES/MHD_NO
  Needed to interpret return values and control flow. While not loop-specific, understanding all return paths is required when reasoning about whether any for-loops (direct or indirect) are well-formed in the overall control-flow.

- POST and GET (connectiontype constants)
  Definitions of these constants (or enum) are required because the code stores them in connection_info_struct; if any loops depend on connectiontype as a loop flag, MISRA rule constraints on loop flags must be checked.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static, MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response, MHD_add_response_header
  These are the primary callees invoked (directly or indirectly) by send_page. Their implementations must be inspected for any for-loops and for side-effects on objects that could be used as loop counters or flags in surrounding for-statements.

Rationale: The MISRA rule concerns the form of for-statements and prohibits using objects that are modified in the loop body in the loop test/update, and also counts called functions as part of the loop body. To determine compliance for any for-loop that occurs in or that surrounds calls made by answer_to_connection, the definitions and side-effects of the above symbols (structures, callbacks, called functions, and constants) must be available so an analyzer can see (a) whether any for-loops exist in those functions and (b) whether those loops or called functions modify objects that would violate the three-clauses constraints or the single-counter constraint.
